items.title: Wheels, Old and New
items.abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A wagon wheel, meant to become a chandelier in a second life.

items.title: Big City, Crazy Killer, Loner Cop
items.abstract: In Warren Ellis’s “Gun Machine” a murderous psychopath who believes he is a resident of pre-colonial Manhattan is tracked by a messy, isolated police detective.

items.title: A Passionate Embrace at the Bus Stop
items.abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A poem about two older people behaving with affection while waiting for a bus to arrive.

items.title: For New York, From Paris, With Love
items.abstract: Metropolitan Diary: After several years in the City of Light, a returning New Yorker tells why she prefers the City That Never Sleeps.

items.title: Ada Louise Huxtable, Champion of Livable Architecture, Dies at 91
items.abstract: Ms. Huxtable pioneered modern architectural criticism in The New York Times, celebrating buildings that respected human dignity and civic history.

items.title: In Israeli City of Haifa, a Liberal Arab Culture Blossoms
items.abstract: The embrace of secularism, feminism and gay rights in the cafes and bars of this cosmopolitan city is creating a counterpoint to Israeli Arabs’ traditional conservatism.

items.title: Woman’s Death in Queens Is City’s First Homicide of 2016
items.abstract: The police at first said there was “no apparent trauma” in the death of Joceline Romo, 19, before the medical examiner’s office ruled it was a homicide.

items.title: De Blasio Names Herminia Palacio as Deputy Mayor for Health and Human Services
items.abstract: The appointment of Dr. Palacio, 54 and a native of the Bronx, fills a key role in the city’s efforts to confront a rise in homelessness.

items.title: A Boutique for the Great Outdoors and the Urban Wild
items.abstract: Snow Peak, newly opened in Manhattan, is more than a camping store.

items.title: State Challenges Plan to Revive City Opera
items.abstract: In a filing in federal bankrupcty court, the New York State Attorney General’s office raises several questions about a proposed reorganization of the defunct opera company.

items.title: In High-Tech Cities, No More Potholes, but What About Privacy?
items.abstract: Cities, including some far from the coasts, are vying to use technology to guide services. But the race toward “smart cities” is raising privacy worries.

items.title: Bright Spot for N.Y.’s Struggling Schools: Pre-K
items.abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s broader plan for public schools has been disappointing, but his universal pre-K initiative shows steady improvement.

items.title: Traffic Deaths in New York City Drop to 200, a Record Low
items.abstract: Fewer people were killed last year in vehicle crashes, a sign that Mayor Bill de Blasio’s Vision Zero plan is working. But pedestrian deaths increased.

items.title: Mexico City as the Director of ‘Roma’ Remembers It (and Hears It)
items.abstract: Alfonso Cuarón revisits the sights and sounds of the neighborhood that inspired his critically acclaimed film.

items.title: How Paparazzi Dogs and Rabbitgirl Conquered New York City Streets
items.abstract: Going around the traditional gatekeepers, Gillie and Marc Schattner of Australia have become the city’s most prolific creators of public art.

items.title: Eric Adams Takes Office as New York City’s 110th Mayor at a Perilous Moment
items.abstract: Eric Adams, the city’s second Black mayor, faces difficult decisions over how to lead New York City through the next wave of the pandemic.

items.title: Nashville Finds Opportunity in the Hole a Bomber Left in the Heart of the City
items.abstract: Since the explosion last Christmas, the city has grappled with how rebuilding will fit into its larger ambitions of transforming downtown. The hope is to draw more than just tourists.

items.title: A New Mayor and a New Relationship Between City Hall and Albany
items.abstract: Unlike their feuding predecessors, Mayor Eric Adams and Gov. Kathy Hochul appear to be getting along. They have their reasons.

items.title: Put a Female Statue on a Vacant Pedestal? An Italian City Says Not So Fast.
items.abstract: In Padua, Italy, a proposal to include a female philosopher in a monument whose 78 sculptures are all men has spurred debate.

items.title: As Omicron Infects Workers, Subway Service Suffers
items.abstract: With coronavirus cases surging in New York, about 21 percent of subway operators and conductors were absent this week, causing suspensions on three lines and changed schedules on others.
